growing.soil: Well-drained, sandy or loamy soil; tolerates poor soils

planting.whenToPlant: Spring after last frost or fall in mild climates
planting.propagation: Seeds, division of clumps in spring or fall, or root cuttings
planting.depth: Seeds should be lightly covered (~1/8 inch)

careAndMaintenance.pruning: Deadhead to extend blooming season; cut back stems in late fall or early spring
careAndMaintenance.stakingOrSupport: Generally not needed, though taller varieties may benefit from support in windy areas
careAndMaintenance.overwintering: Cut back dead stems in fall or leave for winter interest and wildlife; hardy in its zones

harvestingAndUsage.whenToHarvest: Harvest roots in the fall of the plantâ€™s second or third year; harvest flowers and leaves during bloom
harvestingAndUsage.howToHarvest: Dig up roots carefully; snip flowers and leaves with clean shears
harvestingAndUsage.preservation: Dry roots, flowers, and leaves in a warm, airy place and store in sealed containers away from light
harvestingAndUsage.edibleOrToxic: Non-toxic; generally safe when consumed in moderate medicinal doses
harvestingAndUsage.culinary: Not commonly used in cooking; sometimes included in herbal teas
harvestingAndUsage.medicinal: Supports immune system health, may reduce severity and duration of colds; anti-inflammatory and wound-healing properties; used in tinctures, teas, and salves
harvestingAndUsage.aromatic: Mildly aromatic when crushed; not strongly fragrant

funFacts: Native Americans traditionally used echinacea for snakebites and infections.
The name 'echinacea' comes from the Greek word for 'hedgehog' (echinos), referring to the spiny seed head.
